title.narrative: Improving Market Access for the Poor (IMA4P)

description.narrative: Beneficiaries include smallholder and farmer collectives, as in MMW4P, but the scope is now widened to include working with aggregators, traders, domestic and regional markets

Over 5 years VSO will equip over 22,000 poor and marginalised people in Nigeria, Cambodia, Tanzania and Malawi with skills to enhance their economic status, including: agricultural techniques; business development; marketing strategy development; finance management; data and business analysis. Outcomes include increased income and economic security, resulting from enterprise, employment and participation in productive value chains. “Improving Market Access for the Poor” (IMA4P) builds on VSO’s experience, including Global Giving-enabled Making Markets Work for the Poor (MMW4P), VSO’s growing corporate partnerships portfolio2 and recent Enterprise Based Development (EBD) research (resourced by Barclays and Accenture). IMA4P identifies high impact value chains and applies skill-building and other interventions to improve the economic status of poor and marginalised people.

Support skills-building for 22,300 poor and marginalized people in Nigeria, Cambodia, Tanzania and Malawi and enable equal participation in value chains. Project objectives: 1. Support poor and marginalised people to access greater economic and social benefits through removing barriers to participation in selected value chains eg: equipping them in business skills, identifying opportunities for access to finance, support access to distribution channels, influencing government policy 2. Strengthen the capacity of VSO, our partners and local institutions to deliver EBD programmes at scale in selected value chains The programme is split into three components: Market development, skills development and programme management. This approach enables VSO to build on existing and develop new corporate partnerships, including with Accenture, and secure funding from organisations that have strategic interests in selected value chains or the wider agenda of private sector development
Expenditure on Activity costs, staffing and overheads
Funds disbursed for Year 5 Activity costs , staffing and overhead costs
